titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for
Paul W. McCracken Papers, 1940-2000
titlepage.author:
Finding aid prepared by:
Bentley Historical Library staff
Zach Monahan, 2007

did.abstract: Professor of business administration at the University of Michigan, member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers under President Eisenhower, chairman of the Council under President Nixon. Correspondence files, memos, articles, speeches, and photographs.
did.physloc: Offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Mr. Paul W. McCracken (donor no. 5960) over the period of 1977-1996.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Paul W. McCracken Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Paul Winston McCracken was born in Richland, Iowa on December 29, 1915. He graduated with a bachelor's degree from William Penn College in 1937, then received both his master's degree and doctorate from Harvard in 1942 and 1948 respectively.

From 1937 until 1940, McCracken taught at Foundation School of Berea College. Between 1942 and 1943 he worked as an economist in the U.S. Department of Commerce. In 1943 he left the Commerce Department to become financial economist and director of research at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. He remained in Minneapolis until 1948, when he moved to Ann Arbor to join the faculty of the University of Michigan's School of Business Administration.

Since coming to the University of Michigan, McCracken, in addition to teaching, has been active as a senior economic advisor to both private industry and government. In the private sector, he advised numerous corporations, and serves on the board of directors of firms as diversified as K-Mart Corporation, Detroit Edison and Texas Instruments. In government, his most notable appointments have been two periods of service on the President's Council of Economic Advisers. President Eisenhower named his a member of the Council in 1956, a position he held until 1959. In 1969 President Nixon appointed McCracken chairman of the CEA, a post McCracken held through 1971. McCracken has also served in a number of lesser governmental advisory posts.

scopecontent.p: The papers of Paul McCracken have been arranged into six series: Personal; Correspondence; Articles and Speeches; U.S. Dept. of Commerce. National Economic Unit; President's Council of Economic Advisors; Notes on various economic meetings; Visual Materials; and Sound Recordings.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. School of Business Administration.

scopecontent.p: The Personal series (1945-1996) is arranged alphabetically. It is comprised of personal papers including family letters, certificates, and invitations/programs from the White House.

The Correspondence (1959-2004) series makes up the great bulk of the collection It is arranged by date (usually by year or grouping of years) and then by last name of the sender or the first letter of a corporation. This series dates from 1959 to 2004 with a gap from 1964-1971. The researcher should note that although these chronological subseries might be dated (1985 for example), the files themselves will often contain documents both before and after that date. The correspondence in the series is wide ranging, but it primarily reflects McCracken's work as an economist, consultant, or corporate director. Unfortunately, correspondence from McCracken's years as presidential advisor is not part of the collection. See note at the end for their location.

scopecontent.p: The Publicity and Speeches series (1942-2007) contains unpublished speeches as well as published speeches, and papers. Additionally, a large part of the series is dedicated to newspaper clippings and magazine articles containing publicity on McCracken's career at the Federal Reserve Bank, as a member of the U.S. Council of Economic Advisors, as a Professor at the University of Michigan and as an economic expert.

scopecontent.p: The U.S. Dept. of Commerce National Economic Unit (1943) contains memoranda dating from McCracken's involvement with this unit.

The Papers series contains publications, notes, book reviews, and speeches spanning from 1952 until 1996. A large gap occurs between 1959 until 1968 and the bulk of the papers are from the 1970s and 1980s. The scope of the Papers series is quite broad and includes subjects of state, national, and international importance.

scopecontent.p: The President's Council of Economic Advisors series contains a small file of McCracken memoranda from the period during the Eisenhower administration when he was a member of the Council. There is substantially more material from the period of his chairmanship of the CEA during the Nixon administration. Included are memoranda regarding federal economic policy, reports and studies, published materials and newspaper clippings.

scopecontent.p: The Visual Materials series (1970-1986, undated) is arranged alphabetically. It is comprised of photographs and film on videocassettes. Photographs of note include White House Official Photographs of CEA sessions at Camp David and in the Oval Office. Individuals featured include McCracken, Richard Nixon, George H. Bush, Sam Sturgis, and Alan Greenspan.

did.unittitle: United States-Japan Meeting on the Auto Study April 3, 1981
Carl S. Minden, Director of Corporate Relations, University of Utah
Tribute to President Dwight D. Eisenhower January 29, 1986

scopecontent.p: The Sound Recordings (undated) series is arranged alphabetically and features speeches by McCracken on cassette tapes.

did.unittitle: "Can the U.S. Regain its Capability for Orderly Expansion"
Hillsdale College Center for Constructive Alternatives conference

relatedmaterial.head: Related material
relatedmaterial.p: Materials relating to McCracken's terms on the President's Council of Economic Advisors (1969-1970), including meeting minutes, memoranda, correspondence, and topical files, are located in the Presidential Libraries of Richard M. Nixon (56.28 linear feet) and Gerald R. Ford (1.6 linear feet).
